RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Щ atualmente professor adjunto da Universidade Federal do Parс no Instituto de Ciъncias Exatas e Naturais - campus Belщm. Щ doutor em Ciъncias e Tecnologias da Informaчуo pela Universidade de Coimbra, Portugal. Mestre em Ciъncia da Computaчуo pela Universidade Federal do Parс (2012), Bacharel em Ciъncia da Computaчуo (2010) pela Universidade da Amazєnia e Tecnѓlogo em Sistemas de Telecomunicaчѕes (2010) pelo Instituto Federal de Educaчуo, Ciъncia e Tecnologia do Parс. Atua como pesquisador do Centre for Informatics and Systems of the University of Coimbra (CISUC) e membro externo no Grupo de Estudos em Redes de Computadores e Comunicaчуo Multimэdia (GERCOM UFPA). Principais сreas de atuaчуo: Internet-of-Things, Machine-to-Machine communication, Energy-Efficiency, Quality of Experience, routing.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Andrщ Riker is PhD (University of Coimbra), with emphasis in Computer Networks. He received Master in Computer Science at Federal University of Parс , Brazil (2012). Bachelor in Computer Science at University of Amazonia , Brazil (2010); and, Graduated in Telecommunication Systems at Federal Institute of Education, Science and Technology of Parс , Brazil (2010). His research involves: Internet-of-Things, Machine-to-Machine communication, Energy-Efficiency, Quality of Experience, routing.

DOUTORADO.TITULO-DA-DISSERTACAO-TESE: Group communication mechanisms in Machine-to-Machine environments

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO:
This project aims at developing an adaptive system for robot team localisation and navigation using resources provided by wireless ad-hoc networks. The localisation system to be developed in this project rely on both local and global localisation references. Therefore, we assume that there is a central station and only some of the robots can localize themselves using GPS.
Since routing protocols play a major role in Ad-Hoc network, our target is to achieve a proper routing protocol capable of supporting the requirements of the rescue applications.

The focus of the DenseNet project is to study the scalability and survivability (node and network) problems in highly dense networking scenarios. In these dense IoX scenarios, nodes will need to perform different roles, like sensing and actuating to interface with the environment, communication and relaying to carry the information across the network (including gateways and sinc nodes), data fusion and aggregation functions to reduce the data volumes, data replication to increase redundancy, and coordination / decision functions needed to control the overall system, including context aware group management to reduce the number of interacting nodes and guarantee scalability and traffic isolation. The DenseNet project will target efficient communication and scalability in dense network environments through a novel approach where nodes? roles dynamically change over time in order to meet time and space varying multi-objectives, resource constraints and improve network/node survivability. DenseNet will decide dynamically which nodes should perform Sensing/Actuation, Relaying/Communication, Data-Aggregation/Replication/ Fusion, and Decision/Coordination. DenseNet will be able to satisfy multiple goals such as deadline delivery constraints and level of data-accuracy, but the ultimate objective will be to meet these goals while prolonging the network/node survivability in dense environments.
